risk_factors.reasoning: 18-year-old males are more likely to be rearrested due to impulsivity and lack of life experience
being White may not have a significant impact on rearrest rates compared to other factors
10 previous arrests indicate a pattern of behavior that is likely to continue
previous convictions suggest a lack of deterrent effect from past punishments
height and weight may not be significant predictors of rearrest
never being married may indicate a lack of stable relationships or support systems
having a GED certificate and not being enrolled in college may limit job opportunities and increase likelihood of recidivism
holding only one job in the past year may indicate instability or difficulty maintaining employment
past drug use, especially with multiple substances, increases the likelihood of rearrest
not feeling depressed in the past month may not be a significant predictor of rearrest
living with both biological parents at a young age may have provided some stability, but its impact is unclear
growing up in an urban area may expose individuals to higher crime rates and influence behavior
believing God has a role in personal events may not significantly impact rearrest likelihood
